Joel Rose, NPR News, New York.
And that dangerous escape across the Mediterranean is often the final leg of a long and risky trek.
Tens of thousands of people in Africa and the Middle East make that journey, which means smugglers are making lots of money.
We're going to meet one of them now.
NPR's Leila Fadel went for a drive in Egypt for a look inside the business of smuggling migrants.
(Foreign language spoken).
We pick up Abu Ayman in Baltim.
It's on Egypt's northern coastline, hugging the Mediterranean Sea.
By day, the middle-aged Abu Ayman is a fisherman.
By night, he dabbles in smuggling people, many Syrians, into international waters to board other boats headed for Europe, where they're seeking a safer and a better life.
(Through interpreter) We take them.
And we are afraid to take them, actually.
But that's why we are taking them at night.
He asks us just to use his nickname, Abu Ayman, because what he does is illegal, and he's afraid he'll be arrested.
But he does the work anyway.
(Through interpreter) It's good money.
He says for a night of fishing, he's lucky if he makes the equivalent of $65.
But for smuggling someone, he makes about $650 a person.
For each person?
(Through interpreter) For each person.
He'll sometimes smuggle around 20 people on a trip.
Now, he's a small cog in the large smuggling network that spans from Sudan to Libya.
The organizers collect up to $5,000 for each person sent.
Abu Ayman's job is to take migrants through Egyptian waters and hand them off to bigger boats that will ship hundreds at a time toward Europe.
(Foreign language spoken).
He shows us around Baltim.
He points out the sand dunes and palm trees along the water where he's snuck people out to sea in the dead of night.
And he shows us the little holiday huts where the migrants wait until the fishermen pick them up to begin the journey.
(Foreign language spoken).
It has stood for 170 years, withstood a revolution and two World Wars.
It has long outlived the empress for which it was named and the empire she helped rule.
But now, the famous Sisi palm in Vienna must lose its head, like so many royals.
The tree named after Austrian Empress Elizabeth has grown too tall for its home in the palm house of Vienna's Schoenbrunn Palace Gardens.
It must be chopped down before it breaks through the glass-paneled roof.
Well, in fiction, I very much loved the kind of big, epic comic novel that didn't get as much attention as it deserved, maybe because it's so hard to remember the author's last name.
He's Kenyan, and his name was Ngugi Wa'Thiong'O, and the book is called ""Wizard of the Crow.

And although it's set in a kind of African dictatorship where conditions are not great, it's not what you expect - the sort of very somber, tragic kind of spinach, to stay on that theme, sort of book.
It's an incredibly fun, rollicking, satirical - I mean it is a political satire - but there's just a lot of disguises and escapes and mistaken identities and adventure.
And I was just entertained on every single page - so much more so than by that long, long Pynchon book.
And let's see if we can get a nomination from you, Oscar.
Well, for a - my favorite book of the year, in terms of fiction - Cormac McCarthy's ""The Road.
Cormac McCarthy - I didn't even know that he has come out with a new book this year.
Well, he was.
You know, it's rather - I think it's rather brilliant.
It's essentially is an apocalyptic tale, which this - something he kind of gets better and better at writing about.
Well, perhaps, as we get closer to the Apocalypse, yeah.
(Unintelligible) traveling through America, and they're trying to get down town to the sea, perhaps somewhere down the South.
It's a - I think it's very gripping, it's thrilling, it's disturbing.
And the writing in this - some of the best that he's ever produced, which is saying something when you're talking about McCarthy.
And let's see if we can get a non-fiction nominee from both of you.
Why don't we start with you, Oscar?
Well, my non-fiction pick is kind of, I guess, was under the radar, but it was a book that I enjoyed tremendously.
It was the Paris Review, Volume I of their interviews - a clutch of their interviews.
It came out from a (unintelligible).
It's a paperback.
And you know, about 17 bucks, you can spend time with people like Dorothy Parker, Saul Bellow, Jose Luis Borges, Rebecca West, T.S.
Eliot, Richard Price.
And the list goes on.
A non-fiction nominee from you, Laura?

I was a great admirer of Daniel Meddleson's ""The Lost."" Again, it's a story you think you've heard before - a story about someone who decides to investigate what happened to some of his relatives in the Holocaust after hearing a lot of family stories about them.
But it's very, very different from that.
It's a very kind of elegant, almost Proustian story, and it turns out that a lot of the family legends weren't actually true.
And he gets to meditate on why families tell these stories, or why they change - change the facts over time.
We're - also want to get some selections from our listeners.
What did you find under your tree this year?
What did you give out to your friends for the holidays?
E-mail us, talk@npr.org.
And let's begin with Catherine, Catherine with us from Lancaster, South Carolina.
Hello.

In our family - my husband loves military history - so we have ""The Raid on People Harbor,"" ""Flags of Our Fathers: True Stories of D - Day,"" ""Code Talker,"" and ""The Civil War Experience."" And ""The Second World War.
Well, that ought to hold him for a couple of weeks.
Also, I got him a book - a kind of a philosophy book - ""Why A Son Needs A Dad"" so he can reflect about his relationship with his father - which is wonderful - and with our two sons.
And got him ""Take Me Out To The Ballpark."" He's really into sports.
And so it's - like, gives every major ballpark - baseball, major league and minor league.
And it's got, like, diagrams and things like that.
And ""The Civil War Experience.
I got ""Look Homeward, Angel"" by Thomas Wolfe, which is one of my absolute favorites.
The Complete Works of William Shakespeare.
And well, hard to go wrong with Shakespeare.

He studies all week long.

It sounds like you have a very literary family, Catherine.
